content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose strategy B{B} for several reasons. First, even though choosing R gives a higher payoff when the other player chooses B, the difference is only 5$. Over 75 rounds, this difference adds up to just 25$, which is not a significant amount compared to the potential gains from consistently picking B.

Second, if the other player is rational (as I assume they are), they will realize that picking R in the first round gives them a higher payoff if I choose B, but a lower payoff if I also pick R. In order for the other player to maximize their earnings, it would be in their best interest to start by choosing B as well. This means that choosing R in the first round might result in a lower payoff than choosing B, due to the higher chance of getting a 0$ payout if they pick R in response.

By choosing B{B} from the beginning, I am ensuring a consistent payout of 40$ per round for the first 25 rounds (since if they choose R, I get 35$, and if they choose B as well, I get 40$). After that point, we will have enough information to potentially switch strategies to maximize earnings. However, sticking with strategy B gives a consistent payout of at least 40$ per round for the duration of the game, while strategy R has the potential for higher payouts but also the risk of getting 0$. Therefore, I would choose strategy B{B}.
